intro: Rubus biserratus, commonly known as the serrated blackberry, is a species of bramble native to the eastern United States. It is characterized by its thorny stems and compound leaves with serrated edges. The plant produces small, aggregate fruits that are typically dark purple to black when mature. It thrives in woodland edges and disturbed soils, often forming dense thickets. Botanically, it belongs to the Rosaceae family and is closely related to other edible and ornamental Rubus species.
